did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Notes, drafts, and writings on jazz criticism and biography. Also, letters to Balliett and photographs.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Whitney Balliett was esteemed jazz critic. He graduated from Cornell in 1951, and went on to write for The New Yorker. For nearly 50 years, he contributed to the publication with over 550 articles, and many more unsigned. He is known for his non-technical approach to criticism, using artful adjectives and vivid verbs to frame the music. His writing was more poetry than anything, and reading it, one will find metaphors and synesthetic synopses understandable by even the most uninformed music listener.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Notes, drafts, and writings on jazz criticism and biography. Also, letters to Balliett and photographs. The Whitney Balliett collection houses a variety of papers and correspondences from Balliett's career. There are a number of notebooks containing (nearly illegible) notes of various musician's concerts or recordings. There are also items relating to the New Yorker, including a drawing of Buddy Rich by Balliett that appeared in the magazine. Some notable letters include notes from Alice Toklas, John Updike, and Frank Sinatra. Additionally, there are a number of formerly framed items from the wall of Balliett's office.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Whitney Balliett papers, #6948. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

Ghost Experience - Notes about Marian Johnson
Poetry Images... Whitney's Notes for his own Work
American Academy of Artist Letters Program

Bach, Jean (notes on "A Great Day in Harlem")
The Blue Book Guide of the "Sporting District" in New Orleans
Books: James Gould Cozzens Original Manuscript
Book Review: DownBeat - "Ecstasy at the Onion - 31 Pieces on Jazz by Whitney Balliett
Book Review: "God's Perfect Child" by Caroline Fraser
Burns Ken (notes and piece about his Jazz series)
Cain Jackie - Kral, Roy (notes on the singers Jackie + Roy)
Gibson, Dick: Jazz Party - Aspen, Colorado
The Great Hurricane of 1938, Reprint from the New Yorker
"The House and the Highway" - New Yorker

Letters from Cheatham, Doc - Ellis, Anita - Lewis, John
Photo by Jack Bradley, p. 19 - Whitney, Nancy dancing... from DownBeat magazine
Original Manuscript - City Voices: Fourteen New York Portraits
Richard Avedon photograph of Duke Ellington in front of the Apollo theater, signed to Balliett with appreciation.
Henry Groskinsky photo of the members and recipients of awards ceremonial of the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

scopecontent.p: Includes a sheet identifying all people in photo.

did.unittitle: Art Kane photograph Harlem 1958 also known as A Great Day in Harlem, and recreation photograph.

scopecontent.p: The photo depicts 57 jazz musicians. In the more modern, recreated, photo at the same location, ten of the original musicians are pictured. The photo was taken sometime before October 2003.

did.unittitle: Undated photo of Ben Webster in silhouette.
Poster for a performance, "Red Allen, Pee Wee Russell Quintet - Introduced by Whitney Balliett" Poster
Photograph of Balliett with Duke Ellington backstage at the Monterey Jazz Festival.

scopecontent.p: Also in the photo is Nancy and Fred Seligo's date. Fred took the photo at three a.m.

Includes photo of Balliett at home taken by A. Hall, a New Yorker publication with an interview and photos titled "Whitney Balliett and All That Jazz", photograph of drummer Big Sid Catlett by Skippy Adelman circa 1945.

did.unittitle: Pencil drawing on paper of Whitney Balliett playing the drums by Paul Resika
Watercolor and ink drawing for Atlantic Monthly by Barry Blitt.

scopecontent.p: The illustration was for a piece Balliett wrote about playing the drums with a New Orleans group on a jazz cruise in November 1994, which no critics were invited on. It was a ten day voyage on the QE2 from New York City to Antigua.
